newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria tanker explosion said caused by welding.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria tanker explosion said caused by welding.

text.p: A tanker exploded and caught fire in the bay off Lagos on Friday, sending hundreds of workers in the Nigerian city centre rushing from their offices in panic.
"I believe there have been casualties but no one knows for certain yet," said a shipping source in Lagos.
Navy Captain Shuaibu Amodu, head of security at the Lagos port, said the explosion was caused by welding work.
He told the News Agency of Nigeria that a gas cylinder being used for repair work on the tanker exploded, tearing off the bow and setting the ship on fire.
Thick black smoke billowed from the ship. "There is a huge hole in the side of the vessel but it is still floating," a Western diplomat said.
Nigerian shipping authorities said the fire was put out and port operations were normal.
London-based managers of the tanker Al Zainab said it had finished discharging a cargo of naphtha and was entering port to load provisions when the explosion occurred just before noon.
The 29,800-deadweight-ton vessel was built in 1971 and flies the flag of St Vincent and the Grenadines.
Lagos handles general cargo and oil products but not crude oil, which is exported from terminals in eastern ports.
Workers in the city centre feared the blast was another in a series of bombs that have rocked Nigeria's commercial hub in recent months.
Politically volatile Nigeria has been hit by bomb blasts since December. The most recent was at a mosque in the eastern city of Onitsha, killing five worshippers.
